segment.source: Reduce latency with DXGI 1.3 swap chains
segment.target: Reduce latency with DXGI 1.3 swap chains

segment.source: Use DXGI 1.3 to reduce the effective frame latency by waiting for the swap chain to signal the appropriate time to begin rendering a new frame.
segment.target: Use DXGI 1.3 to reduce the effective frame latency by waiting for the swap chain to signal the appropriate time to begin rendering a new frame.

segment.source: Reduce latency with DXGI 1.3 swap chains
segment.target: Reduce latency with DXGI 1.3 swap chains

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Use DXGI 1.3 to reduce the effective frame latency by waiting for the swap chain to signal the appropriate time to begin rendering a new frame.
segment.target: Use DXGI 1.3 to reduce the effective frame latency by waiting for the swap chain to signal the appropriate time to begin rendering a new frame.

segment.source: Games typically need to provide the lowest amount of latency possible from the time the player input is received, to when the game responds to that input by updating the display.
segment.target: Games typically need to provide the lowest amount of latency possible from the time the player input is received, to when the game responds to that input by updating the display.

segment.source: This topic explains a technique available starting in Direct3D 11.2 that you can use to minimize the effective frame latency in your game.
segment.target: This topic explains a technique available starting in Direct3D 11.2 that you can use to minimize the effective frame latency in your game.

segment.source: How does waiting on the back buffer reduce latency?
segment.target: How does waiting on the back buffer reduce latency?

segment.source: With the flip model swap chain, back buffer "flips" are queued whenever your game calls IDXGISwapChain::Present.
segment.target: With the flip model swap chain, back buffer "flips" are queued whenever your game calls IDXGISwapChain::Present.

segment.source: When the rendering loop calls Present(), the system blocks the thread until it is done presenting a prior frame, making room to queue up the new frame, before it actually presents.
segment.target: When the rendering loop calls Present(), the system blocks the thread until it is done presenting a prior frame, making room to queue up the new frame, before it actually presents.

segment.source: This causes extra latency between the time the game draws a frame and the time the system allows it to display that frame.
segment.target: This causes extra latency between the time the game draws a frame and the time the system allows it to display that frame.

segment.source: In many cases, the system will reach a stable equilibrium where the game is always waiting almost a full extra frame between the time it renders and the time it presents each frame.
segment.target: In many cases, the system will reach a stable equilibrium where the game is always waiting almost a full extra frame between the time it renders and the time it presents each frame.

segment.source: It's better to wait until the system is ready to accept a new frame, then render the frame based on current data and queue the frame immediately.
segment.target: It's better to wait until the system is ready to accept a new frame, then render the frame based on current data and queue the frame immediately.

segment.source: Create a waitable swap chain with the DXGI\_SWAP\_CHAIN\_FLAG\_FRAME\_LATENCY\_WAITABLE\_OBJECT flag.
segment.target: Create a waitable swap chain with the DXGI\_SWAP\_CHAIN\_FLAG\_FRAME\_LATENCY\_WAITABLE\_OBJECT flag.

segment.source: Swap chains created this way can notify your rendering loop when the system is actually ready to accept a new frame.
segment.target: Swap chains created this way can notify your rendering loop when the system is actually ready to accept a new frame.

segment.source: This allows your game to render based on current data and then put the result in the present queue right away.
segment.target: This allows your game to render based on current data and then put the result in the present queue right away.

segment.source: Step 1: Create a waitable swap chain
segment.target: Step 1: Create a waitable swap chain

segment.source: Specify the DXGI\_SWAP\_CHAIN\_FLAG\_FRAME\_LATENCY\_WAITABLE\_OBJECT flag when you call CreateSwapChainForCoreWindow.
segment.target: Specify the DXGI\_SWAP\_CHAIN\_FLAG\_FRAME\_LATENCY\_WAITABLE\_OBJECT flag when you call CreateSwapChainForCoreWindow.

segment.source: Note In contrast to some flags, this flag can't be added or removed using ResizeBuffers.
segment.target: Note In contrast to some flags, this flag can't be added or removed using ResizeBuffers.

segment.source: DXGI returns an error code if this flag is set differently from when the swap chain was created.
segment.target: DXGI returns an error code if this flag is set differently from when the swap chain was created.

segment.source: Step 2: Set the frame latency
segment.target: Step 2: Set the frame latency

segment.source: Set the frame latency with the IDXGISwapChain2::SetMaximumFrameLatency API, instead of calling IDXGIDevice1::SetMaximumFrameLatency.
segment.target: Set the frame latency with the IDXGISwapChain2::SetMaximumFrameLatency API, instead of calling IDXGIDevice1::SetMaximumFrameLatency.

segment.source: By default, the frame latency for waitable swap chains is set to 1, which results in the least possible latency but also reduces CPU-GPU parallelism.
segment.target: By default, the frame latency for waitable swap chains is set to 1, which results in the least possible latency but also reduces CPU-GPU parallelism.

segment.source: If you need increased CPU-GPU parallelism to achieve 60 FPS - that is, if the CPU and GPU each spend less than 16.7 ms a frame processing rendering work, but their combined sum is greater than 16.7 ms — set the frame latency to 2.
segment.target: If you need increased CPU-GPU parallelism to achieve 60 FPS - that is, if the CPU and GPU each spend less than 16.7 ms a frame processing rendering work, but their combined sum is greater than 16.7 ms — set the frame latency to 2.

segment.source: This allows the GPU to process work queued up by the CPU during the previous frame, while at the same time allowing the CPU to submit rendering commands for the current frame independently.
segment.target: This allows the GPU to process work queued up by the CPU during the previous frame, while at the same time allowing the CPU to submit rendering commands for the current frame independently.

segment.source: Step 3: Get the waitable object from the swap chain
segment.target: Step 3: Get the waitable object from the swap chain

segment.source: Call IDXGISwapChain2::GetFrameLatencyWaitableObject to retrieve the wait handle.
segment.target: Call IDXGISwapChain2::GetFrameLatencyWaitableObject to retrieve the wait handle.

segment.source: The wait handle is a pointer to the waitable object.
segment.target: The wait handle is a pointer to the waitable object.

segment.source: Store this handle for use by your rendering loop.
segment.target: Store this handle for use by your rendering loop.

segment.source: Step 4: Wait before rendering each frame
segment.target: Step 4: Wait before rendering each frame

segment.source: Your rendering loop should wait for the swap chain to signal via the waitable object before it begins rendering every frame.
segment.target: Your rendering loop should wait for the swap chain to signal via the waitable object before it begins rendering every frame.

segment.source: This includes the first frame rendered with the swap chain.
segment.target: This includes the first frame rendered with the swap chain.

segment.source: Use WaitForSingleObjectEx, providing the wait handle retrieved in Step 2, to signal the start of each frame.
segment.target: Use WaitForSingleObjectEx, providing the wait handle retrieved in Step 2, to signal the start of each frame.

segment.target: The following example shows the render loop from the DirectXLatency sample:

segment.target: The following example shows the WaitForSingleObjectEx call from the DirectXLatency sample:

segment.source: What should my game do while it waits for the swap chain to present?
segment.target: What should my game do while it waits for the swap chain to present?

segment.source: If your game doesn’t have any tasks that block on the render loop, letting it wait for the swap chain to present can be advantageous because it saves power, which is especially important on mobile devices.
segment.target: If your game doesn’t have any tasks that block on the render loop, letting it wait for the swap chain to present can be advantageous because it saves power, which is especially important on mobile devices.

segment.source: Otherwise, you can use multithreading to accomplish work while your game is waiting for the swap chain to present.
segment.target: Otherwise, you can use multithreading to accomplish work while your game is waiting for the swap chain to present.

segment.source: Here are just a few tasks that your game can complete:
segment.target: Here are just a few tasks that your game can complete:

segment.source: Process network events
segment.target: Process network events

segment.source: Update the AI
segment.target: Update the AI

segment.target: CPU-based physics

segment.target: Deferred-context rendering (on supported devices)

segment.target: For more information about multithreaded programming in Windows, see the following related topics.
